stem: The patient with ARDS is mechanically ventilated. Based on the provided information, determine the primary physiological goal for each of the listed ventilator settings and positioning strategies.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 SBAR for Mr. Johnson. Patient is a 68-year-old male admitted 2 days ago with suspected aspiration pneumonia post-stroke. He has since developed ARDS. Onset of increased work of breathing noted at 03:00. 
07:05 Respiratory rate increased from 22 to 34, SpO2 decreased from 94% to 88% on 2L nasal cannula. Patient placed on a ventilator. Initial settings: FiO2 60%, tidal volume 6 mL/kg, PEEP 5 cm H2O. 
07:10 ABG drawn: pH 7.30, PaCO2 55, PaO2 60, HCO3 24. 
07:15 FiO2 increased to 70%, PEEP increased to 8 cm H2O per protocol. 
07:30 Repeat ABG: pH 7.32, PaCO2 53, PaO2 65. 
07:45 Physician ordered prone positioning. Patient tolerated proning well. 
08:00 SpO2 improved to 92% in prone position. Auscultation reveals diffuse crackles bilaterally. Suctioned moderate amount of thick, tan secretions. 
08:30 Currently tolerating ventilator settings and prone positioning. Monitoring respiratory status closely. Continue to assess for skin breakdown related to prone positioning. 
08:45 New order received: Increase PEEP to 10 cm H2O and obtain ABG in 1 hour. Pt education provided to family regarding rationale for interventions. Family verbalized understanding.
09:00 Pt remains hemodynamically stable. Vitals and respiratory status monitored per protocol.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Patient appears anxious and restless.
Respiratory: Increased work of breathing, diffuse crackles bilaterally, moderate amount of thick, tan secretions suctioned.
Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm, no murmurs noted.
Neurological: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
1. Mechanical ventilation per ARDS protocol.
2. Prone positioning, 16 hours daily.
3. Monitor respiratory status and ABGs q1-2 hours.
4. Suction PRN to maintain airway patency.
5. Skin care and pressure ulcer prevention.
6. Nutrition consult.

1. Propofol infusion for sedation.
2. Fentanyl infusion for pain.
3. Vancomycin IV q12h.

rows.text: Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) increase to 10 cm H2O

rationale.correct: PEEP increases the functional residual capacity (FRC) and prevents alveolar collapse at the end of expiration, improving oxygenation. Prone positioning redistributes lung perfusion and ventilation, improving V/Q matching, particularly in the dorsal lung regions. Low tidal volumes (6 mL/kg) are used to minimize lung overdistension and reduce the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) and barotrauma.
rationale.incorrect: Selecting incorrect options indicates a misunderstanding of the physiological effects of ventilator settings and positioning strategies in ARDS. Consider how each intervention affects alveolar recruitment, ventilation-perfusion matching, and lung injury.

answerBreakdown.text: Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) increase to 10 cm H2O
answerBreakdown.rationale: PEEP is used to increase the functional residual capacity (FRC) and prevent alveolar collapse at the end of expiration. This improves oxygenation by keeping alveoli open and available for gas exchange.

Prone positioning redistributes lung perfusion and ventilation, improving V/Q matching. By placing the patient prone, the dorsal lung regions, which are often more affected in ARDS, become better ventilated and perfused.
Low tidal volumes (6 mL/kg) are used to minimize lung overdistension and reduce the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) and barotrauma. This strategy is lung-protective.

clinicalPearls: ARDS management focuses on lung-protective ventilation strategies to minimize ventilator-induced lung injury.
PEEP improves oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse but can also cause barotrauma if set too high.
Prone positioning can significantly improve oxygenation in ARDS patients, but requires careful monitoring and management.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the goals of PEEP and tidal volume. Both impact lung function, but PEEP is primarily for alveolar recruitment, while low tidal volume protects against overdistension.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the primary mechanism of action for each intervention. PEEP maintains alveolar patency, while low tidal volume limits lung stretch.

mnemonic.title: PAL
mnemonic.expansion: PEEP = Alveoli, Prone = V/Q, Low Vt = Avoid Barotrauma
